net.jakubholy.dbunitexpress.assertion
Class RowComparator

java.lang.Object
  net.jakubholy.dbunitexpress.assertion.RowComparator

public class RowComparator
extends Object

A helper class for comparing actual and expected values of the test database' rows using DbUnit. It loads data from the test database into an internal result table (ITable) and provides convenient methods for checking its content.

You may also consider using directly the assert methods for ITable and IDataSet in Assertion, perhaps together with DefaultTable.DefaultTable(String, Column[]).

Standard usage

You would use it as follows from a subclass of DatabaseTestCase: 

 final Product[] expected = new Product[] { ... };
 RowComparator cmp = new RowComparator(getDatabaseTester()
                , "select productId, price from eshop.products order by productId");
 cmp.assertRowCount(3);
 cmp.assertNext(new Object[]{1, 1000.00});      // requires Java 5's autoboxing
 cmp.assertNext(new Object[]{2, 333.50});
 cmp.assertNext("3", "99.0"); // using the convenience String comparison

Subclassing for convenience

You can create a subclass to make verification of your data/objects more convenient, something like 

 private class ProductRowComparator extends RowComparator {

        private final Product[] expected;

        public ProductRowComparator(final IDatabaseTester databaseTester, final Product[] expected) {
                super(databaseTester, "select productId, price from eshop.products order by productId");
                this.expected = expected.clone();
                java.util.Arrays.sort(this.expected); // sort by productId
        }

        public void assertRowsEqual()  throws AssertionFailedError, DataSetException {
                super.assertRowCount(expected.length);
                for (int i = 0; i < expected.length; i++) {
                        assertNext(new Object[]{ expected[i].getProductId(), expected[i].getPrice() });
                }
        }

 }
You would than use it as follows: 

 final Product[] expected = new Product[] { ... };
 new ProductRowComparator(getDatabaseTester(), expected).assertRowsEqual();

assertNext

public RowComparator assertNext(String msg,
                                String[] expectedValues)
                         throws junit.framework.AssertionFailedError,
                                org.dbunit.dataset.DataSetException
Compare the next row (or the 1st one if first use) with the actual data, ignoring differences in type between the expected and actual values. (This as achieved by converting the actual values to String via .toString() before comparing them.)

If you do not care about checking the actual value types this method may be more convenient to use because it's easy to construct strings. Notice that assertNext(String, Object[]) fails if the type of the expected and actual value differs (unless the expected values are passed as an array of Strings).

Parameters:
msg - (optional) A message to add to the AssertionFailedErrors produced
expectedValues - (required) the values to be expected in the columns; the values must be in the same order as columns in the internal ITable.
Throws:
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
org.dbunit.dataset.DataSetException
See Also:
assertNext(String, Object[])

assertNext

public RowComparator assertNext(String msg,
                                Object[] expectedValues)
                         throws junit.framework.AssertionFailedError,
                                org.dbunit.dataset.DataSetException
Compare the next row (or the 1st one if first use) in this.resultTable with the provided expected values and throw an assertion failure if they differ.

If the row differs in a column then an AssertionFailedError is thrown including the row number, name of the column and the expected and actual values.

The type of the actual and expected values is taken into account when comparing them unless expectedValues is actually a String[]. See assertNext(String, Object[]) for type-insensitive comparison.

Using a ValueChecker

You have two options for comparing the actual and expected values: either providing the exact expected value, which will be tested via .equals() or providing an instance of a ValueChecker to which to delegate the check. See an example in its JavaDoc.

Parameters:
msg - (optional) A message to add to the AssertionFailedErrors produced
expectedValues - (required) the values to be expected in the columns; the values must be in the same order as columns in the internal ITable.
Throws:
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
org.dbunit.dataset.DataSetException
See Also:
ITable.getTableMetaData(), ITableMetaData.getColumns(), ValueChecker

assertNext

public RowComparator assertNext(String expectedFirst,
                                String expectedSecond,
                                String expectedThird)
                         throws junit.framework.AssertionFailedError,
                                org.dbunit.dataset.DataSetException
Assert that the values of the next row are same as the three ones provided here after being converted to strings via toString(). This is a convenience method that makes asserting particular values easier (because you don't need to create an Object array and wrap your primitives) if string comparison is sufficient for you.

To be used only if the underlying table has exactly three columns.

Parameters:
expectedFirst - (optional) the expected value of the first column
expectedSecond - (optional) the expected value of the 2nd column
expectedThird - (optional) the expected value of the 3rd column
Throws:
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
org.dbunit.dataset.DataSetException

getResultTable

withErrorMessage

public RowComparator withErrorMessage(String customErrorMessage)
Use this method to set a custom error message that will be added to any subsequent failure message. Call with null to reset.

Example: 


 new RowComparator(aTester, "select * from schema.table")
        .withErrorMessage("The DB should be empty now")
        .assertRowCount(0);

Parameters:
customErrorMessage - (optional)
Returns:
this
See Also:
withOneTimeErrorMessage(String)

withOneTimeErrorMessage

public RowComparator withOneTimeErrorMessage(String customErrorMessage)
Set a custom error message that will be added to the next assert failure message, if it fails, and reset thereafter. While withErrorMessage(String) is persistent and applies to any assert* until it is reset, this one will be reset immediately after the first call to an assert*.

Parameters:
customErrorMessage - (optional)
Returns:
this
